“The Constellations Northern, Some of the Zodiac and Some of the Southern”

div.head: Title
div.p: In the earlier of two surviving fair copies of the poem (see Manuscripts), RF T70, Ruskin centered “THE CONSTELLATIONS” above the column of lines. Then, in what appears an afterthought, he added “NORTHERN” to the right in the margin, on the baseline of the main title; and on a second line below “NORTHERN”, he placed awkwardly in the margin, to the right of the opening lines of the poem, “SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”. The added, trailing subtitle suggests that he extended the title as he expanded the poem, perhaps revealing one reason why he gave up on this fair‐copy manuscript, RF T70, revised some of its lines on the same copy (see Composition and Publication), and made a new fair copy incorporating these changes.

In the second surviving fair copy, in MS III, Ruskin incorporated his revisions to the first fair copy, including allowing space to center the subtitle properly below the main title and above the first line, breaking the three lines as “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”.
The fragment of draft of the poem, which is bound in MS IA, is untitled. The surviving pages begin with lines from the middle of the poem.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Poem; catalogue poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: Facsimile of RF T70 is used by permission of The Ruskin. Facsimiles of MS IA and MS IA used by permission of the John Ruskin Collection, General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Transcriptions of texts and commentary © David C. Hanson.

div.head: MS IA
div.p: In MS IA, one item consisting of a vertically folded sheet contains untitled draft written in pencil on three sides, with some substitutions added in ink.

div.head: RF T70
div.p: A facsimile in the form of two photographs, RF T70, is held by The Ruskin. The photographs apparently were taken during preparation of the Library Edition, but they were not used. The original manuscript shown in RF T70 consisted of a single folded sheet, with text fair—copied on two sides of a single leaf (i.e., pp. 1–2), leaving the other leaf (i.e., pp. 3–4) originally blank. In the photographs, the folded sheet is spread open and laid flat, one photograph showing pages 4 and 1 (from left to right), and the other photograph showing the reverse side, pages 2 and 3 (from left to right).

These facsimiles preserve perhaps the only known instance of a manuscript containing a fair copy of any early work by Ruskin that he subsequently revised using the same sheet. The original fair—copy text of “The Constellations” shown in the photographs is print‐lettered in a small hand, using pen and ink, thus dating the manuscript as no earlier than April–May 1827, when Ruskin first adopted that medium, and probably later in that year, when he had gained more facility (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). Then, at some point after making this fair copy, Ruskin revised various lines of the poem, using a cursive hand that is larger, sprawling, and freer than the original fair—copy lettering. He made his initial revisions in pencil and then in some cases overwrote the penciled cursive revisions using pen and ink, likewise in a cursive hand. Whether Ruskin made the revisions before the original fair copy served its purpose, or revised it after he had made some formal use of the manuscript, cannot be determined.

On the recto of the first leaf shown in RF T70 (p. 1 of the original fair—copy text), Ruskin wrote his revisions in the margin of the fair copy; and on the verso of that leaf (p. 2), he entered his corrections in the margin of the fair copy but extending across the fold into the facing page (originally blank). Here, too, he revised using pencil and then in some cases overwrote the revisions in ink. On the verso of the latter leaf (p. 4), he drafted revised lines in cursive using a pen.

On the last page of the folded sheet (i.e., p. 4), the revised lines of “The Constellations” are written over top of a lighter script of lines that I am unable to connect definitively with any extant fair‐copy juvenilia: “[to(?)] heaven but / not [to(?)] hell [for when (?)] / they went to / place [I(?)] say [that then (?)] / they took quite / a different way / and . . .” (the writing continues for four more, illegible lines). The scrawled draft suggests notes for a sermon, although it might represent attempted revision of “The Constellations” since some lines were given a more pious cast in the final version (see, e.g., the textual notes for the lines “The scales in which twas vainly said / The crime and virtues of men were weighed,” and for the closing meditation on the superiority of virtue to knowledge). No surviving fair‐copy lines, however, even remotely match the faint draft.

div.head: MS III
div.p: Ruskinʼs revisions to RF T70 are incorporated into a fair copy contained in MS III, as the first poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology; hence, this version ranks chronologically as the second known fair copy. MS III is a Red Book, which begins with “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, a work that likewise reflects an interest in astronomy (see Discussion).

div.head: Date
div.p: Cook and Wedderburn ascribe the poem to 1827, citing MS IA and MS III (Works, 2:535). They do not mention the manuscript that they apparently knew at some point in time from the photograph, RF T70, which is presently catalogued among transcripts made for the Library Edition. The editorsʼ dating, judging by their only other mention of the poem, was based on an association of its fragment of rough draft with another fragmentary rough draft, similar in appearance, of “The Monastery” (Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1). The editors bound both fragments in MS IA.

There is no question that the earliest surviving manuscript is the MS IA draft, “cepheus and bootes now”. Its text was the basis for the fair‐copy photographed as RF T70 (or the basis, at least, of the portion of text it represents). In turn, RF T70 became copytext for the MS III fair copy, which incorporates Ruskinʼs revisions in the margins of RF T70 (see Composition and Publication).

Internal evidence suggests that Ruskin may have based the first lines of the poem on actual observation of the sky. The alignment of planets and constellations described at the beginning of the poem would have been observable in April–May 1828, but not at all in 1827 (see Discussion). Physical evidence of both fair‐copy manuscripts, moreover, strongly suggests a date in 1828 for those stages of the poem. Open to question is whether composition of the draft could have begun in 1827, as Cook and Wedderburn supposed.

None of the three manuscripts is dated in Ruskinʼs hand. Of the three, the fair copy in MS III can most securely be dated 1828. Its placement in the Red Book following “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2” and preceding “The Sun”, both of which were completed for New Yearʼs 1828, indicates some point of time after 1 January 1828 for this copy of “The Constellations”. By placing the poem first in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology, immediately following “Harry and Lucy”, Ruskin appears to emphasize a thematic association between the poem and the prose tale, in which Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. It is unknown, however, how much time lapsed between fair‐copying of “Harry and Lucy” and compilation of the poetry anthology, so the the poemʼs placement in the latter, prior to the New Yearʼs poem “The Sun”, does not necessarily argue for composition in the preceding year, 1827.

A factor that would confine a parameter for composition to the first quarter of 1828 is the possibility that certain details were dependent on actual observation of the sky (see Discussion: Observations Actual and Poetic). Those details occur in the opening lines of the poem as fair‐copied; and since those lines are missing from the MS IA draft, this possible real‐life factor cannot be confirmed as an influence on composition. Thus, a genesis of the MS IA draft commencing perhaps in the fourth quarter of 1827 cannot be ruled out (and if the draftʼs opening lines were found to be identical with those in the fair copies, the linesʼ origin in real‐life observation would probably have to rejected). and the first fair copy, RF T70, being produced in winter leading up to New Yearʼs 1828. In a scenario of initial composition in late 1827, the first fair copy would have succumbed to revision, and the second fair copy inscribed into MS III, perhaps in the first quarter of 1828.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Poem previously unpublished in entirety, apart from a single line quoted in Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1.

From surviving documents, a clear chronology is established based on revisions of one document being incorporated in the next. Strikethroughs and substitutions in the MS IA pencil draft contribute to the base text of the fair copy shown in RF T70; and strikethroughs and substitutions in the latter are incorporated into copytext used for the MS III fair copy. This genetic history tracks a similar and roughly contemporaneous record of Ruskinʼs development of the poem, “The Monastery”, as witnessed in manuscripts likewise contained in MS IA and MS III.

As a stage of development in Ruskinʼs compositional methods, “The Constellations” along with “The Monastery” represent a significant advance, which started with learning to use pen and ink in April 1827 (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). For the first time, we see preserved draft containing deletions, substitutions, and insertions, both in pencil and in ink. Perhaps the preservation was accidental, and the MS IA draft manuscripts only seem to bear witness to a maturing process of revision because earlier forms of draft were more ephemeral, such as slate writing. It is equally possible, however, that the rough draft manuscripts in MS IA draft were preserved because they bear witness to a new, more deliberate revision process. The RF T70 manuscript is especially noteworthy, and perhaps unique, as a fair copy that was sacrificed to revision on the same document.

“The Constellations” is also significant for its scope. It is one among several projects of 1828 which are marked by their ambition and length, including the versification of Scottʼs novel, The Monastery, and the “poem on the universe”, Eudosia. Of these three, only “The Constellations” reached a conclusion.

div.head: MS IA Draft
div.p: The item of draft contained in MS IA, “cepheus and bootes now”, is probably a fragment, missing its beginning. Written in pencil in a cursive hand, the fragment starts at line 27 of the poem as fair‐copied, picking up with what reads as the midst of a catalogue of stars already underway. This draft extends for forty lines to the lastȁmentioned of the constellations in all three versions, the goat or Capricorn, which is line 64 of the final version of the poem in the MS III. This final line of the draft in MS IA (2r) includes or is adjacent to the phrase “I end end” (written in part with ink), apparently identifying this line as the original ending of the poem, as conceived at this stage of development. The phrase is omitted from this line, however, as fair—copied in both RF T70 and MS III—the latter two versions carrying on with perorarations of nine lines and fourteen lines respectively (the concluding passage in RF T70 being subjected to considerable revision, which is reflected in the text as fair—copied in MS III).

As originally concluded, therefore, the version of “The Constellations” represented by MS IA was less pretentious poetically, aiming solely at a catalogue of stars. In this respect, the first version of the poem resembles lists of constellations that could be found in various sources (see Discussion: Print Sources). Ruskinʼs chief original contribution to such lists appears to be the epithets describing each constellation, though it must be cautioned that his source remains to be identified, which may have originated or suggested his adjectives.

If some inferences can be drawn from the ending of the MS IA text, nothing can be hazarded about the original beginning. The text starts at the top of 1r of the manuscript, lacking title or context, evidently in mid—career of the poem. (It is possible that the missing, opening piece of the manuscript did once exist as originally bound in MS IA, which in its current state has been damaged and unbound, with possible losses of contents; see MS IA: Contents, b).

The appearance of this draft manuscript is strikingly similar to another item of draft, which was likewise originally bound in MS IA, the surviving draft of “The Monastery” beginning “now must we leave poor martin there” (lines 29–62 of book 2 of Ruskinʼs versification of Scottʼs novel, as fair—copied and numbered in MS III). The two poemsʼ drafts resemble one another in the size and paper used for the physical document, and in the sprawling cursive hand used for the pencil draft. Unlike the “Monastery” draft, the “Constellations” draft was revised by Ruskin with deletions in the form of strikethroughs in pencil, with substitutions written above the strikethrough in pen and ink in a small cursive hand.

Another item of “Monastery” draft that was bound in MS IA, “come on good horse and let us see”, which contains lines 14–62 of book 3 of the poem as fair‐copied in MS III, is written in a cursive hand, one portion in pencil and another in ink. The ink cursive hand, especially in style of punctuation and revision using strikethrough, resembles that used for the revisions of the RF T70 version of “The Constellations”. The physical evidence thus conforms with the probable dating of late 1827 through the first quarter or half of 1828 for the composition of both poems (with an additional stage of composition and fair‐copying of “The Monastery” possibly extending into 1828–29; see “The Monastery”: Composition and Publication).

As remarked in the compositional history of “The Monastery”, the episode of Scottʼs plot narrated in the MS IA draft fragment, “now must we leave poor martin there”, describes how the Englishman, Captain Stawarth Bolton, offers to adopt the two sons of the Scottish widow, Elspet Glendinning—Edward, the younger, and Halbert, the elder. Because this stage of draft and fair copy are ascribed (based on physical evidence) to circa 1828, it can be argued that Ruskinʼs selection of this episode reflects a preoccupation with the permanent adoption of his Scottish cousin, Mary Richardson, into the Herne Hill household following the death of her widowed mother, Jessie Richardson (see “The Monastery”: Composition and Publication—Stage One of Composition; “The Monastery”: Discussion—The Family Context of Composition). Ruskin perhaps cemented composition of “The Constellations” onto this family drama, which underlay composition of “The Monastery”. In “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, which precedes “The Constellations” in MS III, Harry offers to give Lucy “a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”, Lucy assenting that “she would like it very much”. Thus, Ruskin situates the avatar of his cousin in his paper world of text. (In terms of dating, the influence of this family drama does not necessarily confine composition to 1828 since, prior to her motherʼs death in that year, Mary was already resident to a limited extent at Herne Hill in 1827, although at that time enrolled in a boarding school.)

div.head: First Fair Copy (RF T70)
div.p:
Physical similarities connect composition of “The Constellations” with “The Monastery” not only in the cursive pencil and ink hands used for their drafts, but also in
shared eccentricities of ink print lettering used for their respective fair—copies.

The treatment of text in books 1–2 of “The Monastery”, as fair—copied in MS III, has more in common with “The Constellations”, as fair—copied in RF T70, than it does either with what immediately precedes the “Monastery” poem in MS III—namely, the anthology, “poetry discriptive”, which dates from earlier in 1827—or than it does with books 3–4 of “The Monastery”, which are set apart from books 1–2 in MS III (see “The Monastery”: Composition and Publication—Stage One of Composition). For the poems in “poetry discriptive”, Ruskin formed large, spindly characters with pen and ink, which he had learned to use recently, in April and May 1827, whereas he adopted a comparatively miniscule print—lettering, more like a serif book type for “The Monastery”, books 1–2, and for “The Constellations”, RF T70. Moreover, in the “poetry discriptive” poems from earlier in 1827, he avoided punctuation almost entirely, whereas punctuation does characterize the fair copies of “The Constellations”, RF T70, and “The Monastery”, books 1–2; and the punctuation marks are distinctively obsessive and eccentric. Almost every line of books 1–2 of “The Monastery” is punctuated, regardless of any need grammatically or rhetorically, and the marks are used exclusively at the ends of lines. This obsessive but uninformed observance abruptly ceases at book 2, line 80, at the top of page 79 of MS III. Just so, the end of every line of the RF T70 “Constellations” fair copy is notched with a punctuation mark until line 20, where the practice abruptly stops. Where used, the punctuation marks often seem arbitrary. While the full—stop periods usually make grammatical sense, the commas, colons, and (especially in “The Monastery”) an upside—down semicolon seem interchangeable. It appears that, in both these fair copies, Ruskin layered over the texts with bookish punctuation to give the appearance of print, without understanding the grammatical and rhetorical function of the marks—until, that is, he tired of the process and stopped altogether at an arbitrary place. A final bookish touch in both manuscripts is to number the lines by fives in the left margin.

How much time divides these bookish treatments of the longer poems from the earlier 1827 lyric—descriptive poems? “The Constellations”, RF T70, and “The Monastery”, books 1–2, can be triangulated with a third fair copy, that of “Eudosia”, which is dated by Ruskin as 28 September 1828. Here, too, are found the miniscule lettering, the punctuation ending each line until it doesnʼt, and the line numbering on the left. “Eudosia” displays a bizarre punctuation mark formed from two horizontal dots, like a colon on its side or a two—point ellipsis. This mark does not appear in “The Monastery”, where all the colons are right—side up, but the semicolons are upside—down, with the comma atop the point. Thus, these ambitious (and inevitably incomplete) projects—a versified novel, a catalogue of the constellations, and “a poem on the universe”—belong to 1828, although perhaps not all three to the final third of the year like “Eudosia” (and it is not clear to what stage of that poemʼs composition and fair‐copying Ruskin applied that September date). This was the year of the Ruskinsʼ aborted spring Tour of 1828, which was cut short by the death of Jessie Richardson, and followed by a period of mourning, and the resettlement of her children, including the adoption of Mary Richardson into the Herne Hill household.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: For the names and mythological associations of most of the constellations, Ruskinʼs primary source remains to be identified. In this discussion, aspects of his project are contextualized by reference to popular astronomical education in the early nineteenth century. For editorial glosses briefly summarizing the history and mythology of each of the constellations named in the poem, an American text is cited, which was contemporary with the poem and intended for a general audience, Astronomical Recreations (1824) by a chemist, Jacob Green (1790–1841), who produced the book while between professorships at Princeton University and Jefferson Medical College (Smith, “Jacob Green”, 421). Its aim was to provide the casual stargazer with a “view of the relative situation of the fixed stars with regard to each other” along with “directions for ascertaining the position and the name of each particular star” and “remarks on the origin and mythological history of the Constellations” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, v). Up‐to‐date historical information in the glosses derives from Star Tales (2018) by Ian Ridpath.

div.head: Religious Astronomical Education
div.p: As a catalogue simply listing the constellations, Ruskinʼs poem resembles an introductory work for young readers such as An Introduction to Astronomy Intended for Little Children (1817) by Mrs. Sherwood (1775–1851). Starting with a main head identical to Ruskinʼs main title, “The Constellations”, Mrs. Sherwood then subdivides the star groups into lists with explanatory subheads, which likewise resemble the Ruskinʼs subtitle: “Constellations in the Zodiac or Ecliptic”, “Constellations to the North of the Ecliptic”, and “Constellations to the South of the Ecliptic”, with the latter two further subdivided into lists of “Old” and “New” constellations on either side of the ecliptic (Sherwood, Introduction to Astronomy, 12–18). Ruskin either not understanding the ecliptic or disregarding it—Mrs. Sherwood herself delays an explanation of the concept until many pages later, priortizing Bible verses to inspire awe over scientific reason—his poem soon departs from any detectable principle of organization. As his title indicates, the poem first names “northern” constellations fixing on the familiar circumpolar group, but then darts around the celestial globe, naming “some” in the north, “some” in the south, and “some” in the Zodiac, seemingly at random.

If Ruskin deranges an orderly tour of the celestial globe, he invests each constellation with an epithet that lends a poetic coloring without necessarily alluding to its mythological associations (and sometimes contradicting or deflecting from the commonly associated stories). Mrs. Sherwood surrounds her barren lists of names with Bible verses that emblematize the heavenly bodies in general with religious significance. Without mentioning the myths that are standard to a work like Greenʼs Astronomical Recreations, she implies their abomination by quoting Chronicles: “For great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised: he also is to be feared above all gods. For all the gods of the people are idols: the Lord made the heavens” (1 Chron 16: 25–26; Sherwood, Introduction to Astronomy, 14). Ruskin avoids the myths but not the poetry. He also out‐performs the exercise in rote memorization, which Mrs. Sherwood advises in her preface, seemingly modeled on Mrs. Barbauldʼs and John Aikinʼs “opening the budget” in Evenings at Home, but turning that social serendipity into a rigid discipline:

The manner of using these lessons are as follows: the head of each section [e.g., “Constellations in the Zodiac or Ecliptic”], with the beginning of the accompanying [Bible] verse, should be written on a card, and put into a bag, and drawn out indiscriminately for repetition; two or more children passing the bag round in turns, from one to another. Those who are not able to repeat the section, the head of which is written upon the card, are to lose their places, and go to the bottom of the class.

And so on, with additional regimens and penalties, and a specimen of a card with a part for “Astronomy” and a part for “And God said” (Sherwood, Introduction to Astronomy, v–vii). Compared to such rigid memorization, Ruskinʼs poem appears not just random but defiant.

div.head: Patriotic Astronomical Education
div.p: If avoiding either a specifically religious or a specifically profane constellation list, Ruskin does go out of his way to name star groups with patriotic British associations. As an effect of dividing the new from the old constellations, Mrs. Sherwood highlights the seventeenth‐century Carolingian inventions: Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) and Rober Carolinum (Charlesʼs Oak). Ruskin names not only these but also the more recent Telescopium Herschelii (Herschellʼs telescope). Moreover, he lends an English inflection to names where possible: Apus is not the tropical Bird of Paradise but the northern Swallow; Leo is not the fierce Nemean Lion but the “generous” and therefore, one supposes, British kingly beast (see contextual glosses)

div.head: Scientific and Practical Astronomical Education
div.p: Probably the earliest sources of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, and the most cherished, are directly revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. The Tutor points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear end of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).

In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel, the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where Frank can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harryʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.

In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

Ruskinʼs poem “The Constellations” is his answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem along with Harryʼs drawing effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs somewhat random and poeticized listing the star clusters carries out in its own way the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

If Ruskinʼs method in his poem seems random and poetic compared to Mrs. Sherwoodʼs rigid lists, the influence of his Edgeworthian practical and scientific reading is perceptible in the opening of “The Constellations”, where he adapts Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tactic of starting from a prominent point of reference in the sky—not, in Ruskinʼs case, a constellation, but a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, a wandering rather than a fixed star. In this instance, Venus is associated with the constellation Orion as these bodies fall below the horizon in the west, and then the poem re‐orients to the circumpolar constellations overhead. Following this practical introduction, Ruskin carries on to list the formations supposedly in a sequence, the lines of the poem clicking along by repeating “next”, but the organization becomes erratic, albeit with some elements of logic (see Real‐life Observations).

div.head: Beyond the Books: Theatrical and Other Popular Sources of Astronomical Instruction in Early Victorian Britain
div.p: It is possible that Ruskin produced this poem by relying entirely on print sources, albeit not a single source. While Joyceʼs, Dayʼs, and Maria Edgeworthʼs books are proven influences, their books refer to only a handful of the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem. The addition of a tabular source like Mrs. Sherwoodʼs, combined with Ruskinʼs imagination, could account for the whole, but “The Constellations” hints at a still larger context of early Victorian astronomical instruction in the form of lectures, toys, and just real‐life observation. Did Ruskin engage in actual stargazing as preparation for any part of the poem? Does the poem reflect conditions of British astronomoical practice and popular education in the 1820s? Evidence is limited, but the introduction to astronomy provided by Ruskinʼs books itself pointed to the theatrical and real‐life entertainments that were readily available to youth.

div.head: Observations Actual and Poetic
div.p: As indicated by Ruskinʼs sources, “The Constellations” is a bookish poem. Even in Ruskinʼs books, however, tutors begin study of astronomy by directing their pupilsʼ attention to the evening sky. To what extent, if any, might Ruskinʼs composition of his poem have involved actual observation? Ruskin opens his poem by hailing Venus and Mars. Planets are not an obvious starting point for charting the constellations: tutors in Ruskinʼs books typically begin by asking pupils to find Charlesʼs Wain. As suggested by an earlier poem, “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Glen of Glenfarg thy beauteous rill”), Ruskin had long been able to orient himself that far to the night sky. Equally striking objects for young stargazers are Venus, the Morning Star or Evening Star, and Mars, the red planet. Ruskinʼs observation of the alignment of those planets could also lend support to dating of the poem.

In the poem, Ruskin positions Venus specifically as the Evening Star near the constellation Orion. According to a digital‐age star chart, the Sky & Telescope Interactive Sky Chart, Venus would have been visible from London as the Evening Star, setting in the west along with Orionm during April–June 1828. During those same months, Mars would have risen from the east, traveling “high . . . [in] the sky” a few hours after Venus had set.

This particular configuration of Venus, Mars, and Orion did not appear at any other time in 1828, and did not occur at all in 1827. Astronomically, then, the poemʼs introduction aligns with the evidence in Composition and Publication supporting the year 1828 as a probable period of composition or at least revision. April–May was the period when Ruskin tyically prepared poems for his fatherʼs birthday in May, thus suggesting an occasion as well as a terminus a quo for the start of either composition or revision of “The Constellations” (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 12 April 2023). This convergence of evidence enables us to imagine also that Ruskin looked up from his books to the sky for a phenomenon with which to open his poem.

Even so, that search for Orion was likely inspired by Tommy Merton, who, “looking up to the sky . . . observed so remarkable a constellation, that he . . . begged to know the name”. On learning it was called Orion, he “was so delighted with the grandeur and beauty of this glorious constellation, that he could not help observing it, by intervals, all the evening; and he was surprised to see that it seemed to pass on, in a right line drawn from east to west; and that all the stars he had become acquainted with moved every night in the same direction”. In the opening four lines of the poem, Ruskin echoes the alliterative modifiers with which Mr. Barlow describes the experience of gazing at the constellations: “‘I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us’” (Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 187–88, 165 [emphasis added]).

The bodies above that were visible at all times of the year to British youth were the circumpolar constellations—the “northern” constellations, as Ruskin specified among the classifications tagged onto his main title. Of the constellations named in lines 7–11 of Ruskinʼs poem, only Charlesʼs Wain is mentioned by the tutors in Dayʼs and Joyceʼs dialogues. An observer in April 1828 could, however, easily have followed Ruskinʼs cues by looking up from Orion setting in the west to trace the poemʼs network of constellations overhead. Locating Ursa Major (the Great Bear) in the center of the sky, the observer would find the “pointer” stars embedded in Charlesʼs Wain (which forms part of Ursa Major), using these to trace a path to the tip of Draco (the Dragon)ʼs tail. Following the wind of the tail toward the northeast, the observer would turn to the east to encounter Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown). Continuing to circle counter—clockwise back toward Ursa Major, the observer would have found the next named constellation in the poem, Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair).

Hereafter in Ruskinʼs poem, following the mapping of the circumpolar constellations, the sequence of constellations becomes more erratic, with Ruskinʼs repeated “next comes” ceasing necessarily to refer to formations that are adjacent in the dome of the sky. In the second fair copy, in MS III, Ruskin forestalled objections by adding the a note with the caveat: “These constellations though they are next in this poetry are not next in the sky”. It is impossible to know whether he added the note because he only then discovered the confusion or because he was prodded to justify a more poetic than naturalistic procedure that he had adopted from the start.

div.head: Names versus Numbers: The Mythology of the Constellations and Modern Astronomy
div.p: Certainly the poem is interested more in naming than in mapping; the poem is a catalogue, not a star chart. At the same time, neither is it a narrative—despite mythic storytelling being the expected alternative to a scientific or practical approach. If Ruskinʼs poetic naming suggests a distant and, in some cases, contradictory relation to the myths commonly associated with the constellations, that reticence could be explained not only by religious objections to heathenism but also by scientific disapproal of superstition. In Joyceʼs dialogues on astronomy, the Tutor and his scholars are dismissive of mythology, though easily prompted to quote descriptive poetry:

James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones”;.
Tutor. “Nor do I.”
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, 2:36–37).

Instead of myths, the lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky whereby the ancients ordered and named the constellations, the Tutor emphasizes, were arbitrary constructions:

Tutor. “The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented”.
Charles“It is then perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on”.
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 13–14).

The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, 23). As a more sophisticated system, the Tutor leads his pupils from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain to a celestial globe, which he uses to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator; and then he directs the boys to an ephemeris, a catalogue of star positions (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversations 2–4, 12–47). Modern ephemerides were based on exacting observations and mathematical computations, which were the pride of scientifically advanced nations that produced these star catalogues. It has been argued, however, that their forbidding tables made the ephemerides a “primary culprit” in driving away public interest in astronomy, displacing the appeal to popular imagination that the stars had presented in the annual almanacs with a professionalization of the science that seemed inaccessible to omateur “sky‐loving men”, in Ruskinʼs phrase (Donnelly, “On the Boredom of Science”, 493–97).

As a less exacting task, Dayʼs Mr. Barlow contrives a paper globe on which Tommy and Harry can draw the constellations (The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, 187). Ruskinʼs poem can perhaps be viewed as an ersatz globe, listing constellation names in a sequence that oscillates back and forth from west to east and back again, or that possibly (in places) circles counter—clockwise—a pattern, if he intended any pattern at all, that Ruskin could have plotted only by referencing a celestial globe or illustrated star charts in a book.

One can test this theory by searching for a pattern in Ruskinʼs sequence of constellations. At line 12, following the circumpolar constellations, the next listed constellation is Cygnus (the Swan). Assuming, for consistencyʼs sake, the hour of Orionʼs setting in the west in April 1828, Cygnus would have lain on the northeast horizon, beyond Draco. Then the following item, Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) would have directed the viewer back toward the center of the dome, within Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), between Ursa Major and Coma Berenices. For the next, the now obsolete constellation, Herschellʼs Telescope, one would have turned back toward the west, where it would have been rising as Orion was setting, located within Auriga (the Charioteer). The next, Equuleus (Little Horse), is found between Pegasus and Delphinus, which would have lain back toward Cygnus, rising on the northeast horizon as the evening advanced on April 28. The next named constellation, the Goose (Anser), does keep within range of Equuleus; however, to get from Goose to Hare—Anser to Lepus (hare)—again sends one in the opposite direction, to the feet of Orion.

At this point in the RF T70 draft, Ruskin originally cited Lyra (the Lyre), which he replaced with Lepus (Hare). Since Lyra is found in the same quadrant as Anser and Cygnus, by substituting Hare, which lies at Orionʼs feet, Ruskin maintained a pattern of back‐and‐forth, west‐to‐east and back again (or counter‐clockwise circling), but in naming Hare he also dropped below the celestial equator to “some of the southern” constellations, as his title mentions. A few lines later, he will plunge into the corresponding southern constellations on the opposite side with Crux (Southern Cross). It seems to break the pattern that, intervening between these southern constellations, Ruskin lists Ursa Minor (Lesser Bear), which contains the Pole Star, but perhaps he paused midway across the sky only to rhyme hare and bear. He may also have wanted Ursa Minor. to stand as a barrier between Anser, “stupid goose”, and “cunning fox” (Vulpecula), which follows Ursa Minor in the list. Traditionally, Fox and Goose were treated as a single constellation, Vulpecula et Anser, with the Goose caught in the Foxʼs mouth (Ridpath, Star Tales, 182–83). By separating them, Ruskin characteristically avoided violence.

It seems a foolʼs errand to look for an equivalent of Mr. Barlowʼs paper globe in what Ruskin himself characterized as a poetic order—“constellations . . . next in this poetry . . . not next in the sky”. Whatever poetic idea directed his eye (and intriguingly, governed his choices for revision) in moving from constellation to constellation, the most dramatic poetic evolution of the poem lay in the addition and revision of the poemʼs conclusion in the two fair copies. For this development, Ruskin may have looked neither to a real nor a paper sky, but to a theatrical projection.

div.head: The Lenten Astronomy Lecture
div.p: After , Ruskin arrives at the Zodiac, as also mentioned in his title, which may hint at another context for his interest in astronomy. As a distinct activity from professional astronomy with its mathematical orientation combined with observation—the less popularly accessible approach, which Joyceʼs Tutor encourages over the mythological tradition—there thrived in the 1820s a popular form of astronomy education, which combined technology with art, modern science with traditional elements such as the Zodiac. The popular astronomy lecture was a theatrical entertainment, commonly known as Lenten astronomy lectures since they could be held in London theaters during the holy season, when plays were forbidden. The timing of these spectacles fits with the proposed April–June 1828 period for composition of “The Constellations”, which might have been initiated by attendance at a lecture. (In 1828, Easter Day fell on 6 April. John James Ruskinʼs accounts for April 1828 include “Abernethys Lectrs” for 12s, but this entry probably refers to published lectures by the surgeon, John Abernethy [1764–1831]; Account Book, 6r).

The astronomy lecture circuit—originating in the late eighteenth century, becoming a craze in the 1820s, and remaining a staple of popular science instruction at least until mid—century—has been researched by Hsiang—Fu Huang, who finds that its performative and entrepreneurial aspects overlapped with the insitutional framework of lecturing that was supposedly displacing these popular forms of instruction in the 1820s (Huang, “A Shared Arena”). A target audience for the lectures included children, as Huang notes (“When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 60–61), astronomy being regarded as an uplifting area of knowledge religiously as well as scientifically. As a guidebook of London amusements solemnly assured parents about the content of Lenten astronomy lectures—even as performed by George Bartley (1784–1858), who was not a scientist but a comic actor, famed for his portrayals of Shakespeareʼs Falstaff—the spectacle would convey “to the minds of their children the lofty and magnificent ideas that Astronomy supplies”—namely,

Beauty, Order, and Sublimity in the Heavens, [which] appear to their expanding intellect, in all their delightful prospects; and the feelings, that will certainly influence their entrée into life, will be characterized by a marked reverence for that “Divinity which breathes within us, / And points out an after state to man”. Adults, as well as children, will derive, from this exhibition, an increased perception of the power, dignity, and ubiquity, of that Being whom we ought to serve.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 4; on Bartley, see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 54–57)

Even as educational entertainments for children, however, the Lenten astronomy lectures were regarded with some criticism by educators, as Ruskin would have known from Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank. After Frank has attempted and failed on his own to construct an orrery, a model of the solar system, his parents take him and his cousin Mary to an astronomy lecture at a theater. The performance features something like the large—scale, illuminated or “transparent” stage orreries with Greek—inspired names like Eidouranion, which combined the older mechanical, three—dimensional orrery that reproduced the revolutions of the sun and planets with transparancies projected by a magic lantern (see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 49–51, 66 n. 23). For Edgeworth, criticism of these spectacles pertains not just to quack lecturers and creaky, dysfunctional orreries, which Huang finds in satires of the day (“When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 62–63); more fundamentally, Edgeworth points to conflicts with reformersʼ principles of effective pedagogy.

The theatrical spectacle is a grand but passive presentation, discouraging learning through experience and self—discovery. Even though Frank had failed to complete his own orrery because he over—reached his abilities, the stage orrery is “particularly interesting to Frank” thanks only to “the pains he had taken, and the various attempts he had made, to understand and to represent” the revolving bodies. The other “little children” in the audience went “dead asleep” and “even he”, Frank, “after all his reading in Scientific Dialogues, had much difficulty sometimes in understanding both the machine and the lecturer”. Edgeworthʼs most severe criticism is aimed at the failure to scale knowledge to the age—appropriate accessibility of young listeners. The lecturer overwhelms the audience “with a vast number of words, which” Frank “strained his attention” to understand, trusting that the lengthy explanations “were all necessary”, yet “of which nearly half were nothing to the purpose” and put Mary to sleep altogether. As for the London guidebookʼs promise of the theatrical augmentation of Beauty, Order, and Sublimity, it is the sight of the real moon on the ride home that prompts a spontaneous reaction from Mary: “‘How beautiful!’ said she: ‘and how—’ sublime! she would have said, but she did not know the word well enough: she knew the feeling.” Feelings are represented as accessible, regardless of age and learning; and despite Edgeworthʼs promotion of the Industrial Sublime in Harry and Lucy Concluded, here Frank responds to Maryʼs admiration: “How wonderful! What is the orrery compared to this, Mary! . . . How grand! how different from any thing that the most ingenious man in this world can make!” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:251, 253, 255, 249, 256, 257).

The opposite effect on children was promised by promoters of astronomy as a theatrical spectacle: astronomical science in particular, it was argued, benefits by the intervention of art. According to the 1826 guidebook, astronomy lectures are the epitome science enhanced of metropolitan “improvements and amusements”:

Astronomy, universally acknowledged the most sublime and interesting of those sciences which admit of popular illustration, is doubly valuable for its powerful influence and effect in the general improvement of the human mind. . . . {T}he science of astronomy is . . . the very science of which a popular display may most successfully be aided by the ornamental arts. Music, painting, sculpture, may be called in as auxiliaries, with powerful effect, and manifest benefit; a tasteful introduction of poetry may be deemed almost essential to success; and we would undertake that Urania need not disdain the co—operation of Terpsichore herself.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 3; see Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 47)

Wellbeloved devotes two pages describing in detail how a new “hydraulic” orrery has improved on older “instruments . . . hitherto . . . constructed by a complication of wheel—work, which, although extremely ingenious, are nevertheless almost unequal to the imitation of those equable, silent, and undeviating movements, which characterize the grandest works of the Creator”. Yet, despite the interest the reader is assumed to take in two close pages of technical description of how hydraulic improvements have brought the orrery closer to the operations of the Creator, the accompanying engraving sets the machine in a “design of our own”—a moonlit natural landscape like the scene that impresses Mary and Frank as tending to the disadvantage of technology (London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 6–7).

Despite these conflicts with the Edgeworthian basis of Ruskinʼs education, some elements of the Lenten lectures correspond to Ruskinʼs poem. The lectures appear to have presented a somewhat uniform set of topics. In Edgeworthʼs fictional treatment, the topics resemble those listed in An Epitome of Astronomy . . . as Illustrated by the Eidouranion, a pamphlet published to accompany lectures by the Walker family, first published in 1782 and here quoted from the edition of 1812:

list.item:
Scene 1. “The Sun and Earth: with the Zodiacal Constellations” (p. 6).
“This scene is surrounded by transparent paintings of the twelve signs of the Zodiac, shewing how the Sun, or rather the Earth, enters and passes through Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, &c.” (p. 8).
Scene 2. “Sun, Earth, and Moon: Phases and Eclipses” (p. 9).

Scene 3. “Theory of Tides” (p. 13)
In Frank: A Sequel, “By this time the lecturer had come to an explanation of the cause of the tides, which neither Mary nor Frank could comprehend. His father judiciously and kindly took them out to rest their attention, and refresh themselves while this lasted. They went into a cool room, where they eat oranges and biscuits, and drank lemonade, till the tides were over” (2:252).
Scene 4. “The Solar System” (p. 16), including “Four New Planets” (p. 23) and “Comets” (p. 29).

Last Scene. This final scene is not announced in the pamphlet by a separate heading, as is the case with the four preceding scenes, but embedded in a peroration on the infinitude of the universe: “. . . how in adequate must the utmost stretch of finite faculties be to represent infinity! The stars, disposed in constellations, and surrounded by concentric circles, may perhaps assist the imagination a little: The attempt in the LAST SCENE, if not admired, we hope will be forgiven. But was it possible we could actually take our flight into infinite space, or be borne on the wings of lightning, to the most distant fixed Star we can now see, even there, perhaps we should find ourselves on the confines of creation, and see as many stars before us as we left behind! For space has neither top nor bottom in it; it is a circle whose centre is every where, but whose circumference is no where!” (pp. 36–37).

div.p: According to this description, the “Last Scene”, at least as delivered by the Walker family, which by 1828 had passed into the management of Deane Franklin Walker (1778–1865 [Huang, “When Urania Meets Terpsichore”, 50]), the most comprehensive view of the constellations was presented as the finale. Could Ruskin have conceived of his poem as an ekphrastic version of this final, totalizing scene? Apparently, in this show, a transparency exhibited a circle of the starry night, surrounded by concentric rings to suggest infinitude. In an engraving by I. Stow (ca. 1770–1823), after E. F. Burney (1760–1848), The proscenium of the English Opera House in the Strand, (Late Lyceum.) as it appeared on the Evening of the 21st March 1817, with Walkerʼs Exhibition of the Eidouranion, published by Robert Wilkinson, Scene 1 represented the earth and sun by turning the orbit vertically to the audience, enclosing this revolution of the Eidouranion within a projection of an outer ring, which showed the Zodiac constellations. The Zodiac constellations were represented by their respective mythological figures. Perhaps the transparency for the Last Scene exhibited a similar ring of constellations in their mythological guise, which Ruskin in his way has reproduced.

The beginning of the poem, however, starts with a version of Scene 1 in the Walkersʼ exhibition—or more precisely, a portion of their Scene 4—with the rising and setting of Venus and Mars. As noted earlier, the poem is atypical of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs introductions to the constellations, which begin with finding the circumpolar constellations in the sky. Ruskin incorporates that observation as the second stage of his poem. The Zodiac constellations form a distinct piece within the poem. The most significant point to draw from the context of the Lenten astronomy lectures is that Ruskinʼs catalogue may have attempted a sublime totality, an expression of religious awe.
